ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I practiced my Spanish speaking and writing skills via class discussions and writing assignments on social, economic, and political issues. This class was fantastic at improving my comfort with Spanish. The focus was not on vocabulary or grammar but rather on practice with feedback.
My Spanish skills got way better. My writing and vocabulary in teased. However this professor gave me the confidence to be proud of my improper Spanish.

I feel a lot more comfortable speaking Spanish to strangers now after taking this course. It built up my vocabulary in topics I've otherwise had no exposure to. My mom says my Spanish is better too :)
Ability to have difficult and complex conversations in Spanish and relate to current events in the Spanish-speaking world.
Became better at speaking and hearing Spanish.

- Refinement in spoken Spanish grammar and punctuation
- Expanded vocabulary of words and structures in Spanish
- Perspectives on justice and injustice in education, medicine, urban planning, and law in the Spanish-speaking world
- Increased comfort and fluency communicating with native speakers on the topics above
Became a lot more proficient in my ability to speak Spanish and learned a lot about the various healthcare systems, educational systems, and legal/political issues of the Spanish-speaking world.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths of this course included Professor Mendez-Seijas and his enthusiasm and passion for our learning. He was kind, helpful, and invested in our class discussions, in addition to responding to student feedback and input. I don't think there were any weaknesses at all.

The strength of this course lies in Jorge. He is the best language professor I have had at Yale. Coming into the class, I felt a little behind compared to my classmates, some of whom are heritage speakers. However, Jorge was very fair and understanding and always willing to help me improve my writing and oral skills. Despite it being a language course, this course also opened my eyes to many cultural nuances in Latin American countries, specifically with topics like disparity in the education and health system. Overall, there is no weakness (maybe besides the fact it meets three times a week for an L5 class). I recommend you take a class with Jorge if you can.

Strengths: format of the class, the themes talked about were intriguing. 
Weaknesses: none
The structure of the course is fantastic and very easy to follow. Jorge outlines the expectations for the class very clearly and reiterates them concisely throughout the weeks.

I truly cannot think of any weaknesses of this course. Professor Mendez-Seijas is one of the most talented educators I've ever encountered, and the learning materials and topics of this course were fascinating, engaging, and illuminating. The workload was not overwhelming- there were no exams and no huge stressful projects. Rather, each class was a discussion, and the homework was to prepare for the next discussion (in addition to a short weekly writing assignment and a biweekly speaking assignment). Amazingly organized class.
Strengths: awesome classroom environment, all due to our fun group of classmates and also Jorge being a lively, intelligent, dedicated teacher.

The variety of units in this course offer something for everybody. The 200-word writing assignments were long enough to generate substantive feedback but short enough to be manageable; I almost wish that there had been more. Group discussion in class was significantly more active than in lower levels, with dialogue, disagreement, and discussion filling the air in most meetings. The layout of units and lessons made sense and was interesting. The variety of sources (articles, documentaries, speeches, essays) helped us interact with the language in a variety of ways.

The last unit, on constitutional design, could use some refinement. It's tough to write somebody else's constitution, because constitutions should have a special relationship with the history and tradition of the people who live with them. As an outsider, it can be difficult to pay appropriate respect to these dynamics; one way to get a little closer would be to pick a single country instead of trying to do all of Latin America at once. Alternatively (and I think that this is more in line with the spirit of the unit) the project could focus on a declaration of rights, which are usually meant to be more universal.

Most of the topics of this course were incredibly engaging and personally relevant to me as a Latino, which kept me very engaged.  My only gripe is that there was oftentimes too much of a focus on Spain as opposed to Latin America and the U.S.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course as a great choice for an L5 credit, especially if with Professor Mendez-Seijas. The workload is not too high, and the professor is fantastic.
YES!! You will learn so much from Jorge and your classmates.
Yes. It is a perfect introductory level five class. For those that are fluent or at the level 5 it is a perfect transition into college spanish.
Absolutely. The professor was amazing and always came to class excited to teach.
This course was fantastic but will likely change in future semesters (and the instructors will be different). I really enjoyed taking it nonetheless.
This is one of the best classes I've ever taken at Yale and I'm sad that Professor Mendez-Seijas will not be teaching it next year. The learning materials were excellent and engaging.
YES. Jorge is awesome I love that man.

Yes. This class continues the best parts of lower level Spanish classes--especially the variety of topics and assignments--with more flexibility and freedom and less rigid structure and workload. My classmates were generally dedicated and active in class and I feel like I really improved my Spanish communication. Exactly what it promises to be and exactly what I was looking for.

Even if you feel confident in your ability to read, write, and speak in Spanish, I would highly recommend this course as the topics this course covers to help students gain proficiency in the language are in and of themselves incredibly interesting and fun to study/discuss.

extras.title: SPAN 150 01 - Adv Oral and Writ Com in Span
